headline: Spam Musubi
description: Making Spam musubi at home is easy. This wildly popular Hawaiian snack features seared canned ham prepared sushi-style with rice and nori. Very yummy!

video.description: Marinated and cooked slices of SPAM® on top of seasoned rice, wrapped in a piece of nori.
video.name: SPAM® Musubi

name: Spam Musubi
recipeIngredient: 1 (12 ounce) container fully cooked luncheon meat (such as Spam)

recipeInstructions.text: Soak uncooked rice in water to cover for 4 hours; drain and rinse.
Bring 2 cups water to a boil in a medium saucepan. Add rice and stir. Reduce heat, cover, and simmer for 20 minutes.
Remove pan from heat and stir in rice vinegar. Set aside to cool.

Stir together sugar, soy sauce, and oyster sauce in a medium bowl until sugar is completely dissolved. Slice luncheon meat lengthwise into 10 slices, or to desired thickness, and marinate in sauce for 5 minutes.
Heat oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Cook slices until lightly browned, about 2 minutes per side.

Cut nori sheets in half and lay on a flat work surface. Place a rice press in the center of a sheet, and press rice tightly inside. Top with a slice of luncheon meat, and remove press. Wrap nori around rice, sealing edges with a small amount of water. (Rice may also be formed by hand in the shape of the meat slices and about 1-inch thick.)

review.reviewBody: Super yummy!. Didn't have a rice press, but managed to mold by hand. I reduced the sauce after marinading the Spam, then spread that on the rice before adding the Spam. Also added rice seasoning to add a little extra. Loved the flavor.

I always like to try the recipe as is the first go and changed it up from there. Don't think I'll change anything! This was delicious. Might try baking the Spam as someone suggested, but this was great!

This recipe is so salty. I used low sodium spam and soy sauce and it was still astronomically salty. The sweetness is an afterthought, and the rice was way too vinegary. I personally prefer the more traditional method: just rice (with or without sushi seasoning of a bit of vinegar and sugar), spam, soy and sugar. As other reviewers have said, you fry up the spam with just a tiny bit of Pam or no oil at all, then add the sugar and soy to the pan allowing it to caramelize. Marinating it is salt overkill, as is the oyster sauce.

I love this recipe! I have made this several times and I have tried it with and without the oyster sauce and actually prefer it with. It just adds a little more oomph to the flavor. Here are the slight tweaks I have made. I don’t add vinegar to the rice ( I did before and prefer it without), I actually marinate my spam a little longer at least 15/20 minutes per side as it lets it soak up more of the flavor from the sauce. I use an old spam can for my rice mold and I add furikake to the rice then add the spam on top. You can even add a little of the left over sauce on the rice as well for more flavor. I wrap with seaweed and water helps seal it together. Then wrap in
5 stars!!! Lived in Hawaii and have family there still. always got musubi for a snack. Just like minit stop.
I rarely give 5 stars! Recipe was easy - my 1st time with sushi rice & seaweed wrap - & the tasty marinades enabled my daughter & I to hit it out if the park.
Loved it!
Perfectly Yummmm just what the family wanted!
Yummy!!!

I’ve tried many musubi recipes and this one will be my permanent one! The only thing I would do differently next time, is I wouldn’t use so much rice vinegar in the rice (I didn’t soak for 4 hours; just cooked as usual). The vinegar taste and smell was so overpowering. I even added two more cups of unseasoned white rice, and added scrambled eggs to the musubi, and the vinegar was still so strong. Maybe only 2 tbl would be enough; just enough to get the rice the right consistency. I also burned the first patch of musubi.I turned the heat down, scraped off excessive marinade, and kept a closer eye on the rest and they come out perfect.
Came out perfect!! Great recipe, very flavorful. Made it for a Hawaiian themed birthday celebration. Thank you for sharing.
The family loved them!
Thank you for this simple recipe of spam musubi. My friends and family loved it

I have to admit, I’ve made these about a dozen times but I have never tried it. My husband is the one who LOVES them and the only one who eats them. He isn’t a fan of the fishy or vinegar taste tho so I omit the rice vinegar and don’t sub anything in place of it. I also double the soy sauce and omit the oyster sauce. Tastes just like the ones he gets in Hawaii so he’s a huge fan.
I've missed eating musubi since moving! I can't believe I found this recipe! They taste just as I remember them! Great recipe! Thank you! I tried them with different toppings as well!

Surprisingly good! Never had spam musubi before or even spam but wanted to give it a try. I adjusted the sauce to my liking my adding a healthy amount of ginger as well as ponzu sauce and hoisin sauce. Ate it with some wasabi and it was awesome!

This recipe is so yummy, only complaint is the sugar amount! I would put 1/3 instead, too sweet for me but other than that it’s amazing! Great snack on the go to, just wrap it in some Saran Wrap and you’re all good to go! Also, instead of cooking rice with the vinegar I cooked the rice separate and then added 3 table spoons of sushi rice vinegar and it tasted just as good!

The sauce was just perfect in flavor, just like in Hawaii! I like seaweed so I made it a wide wrap. (I can see why they use narrow strips because it gets tough to bite thru without the filling getting squeezed out.)

Keep a small bit of water nearby to keep your hands wet and nonsticky for forming the rice. Great to wrap individually in plastic wrap for a filling snack.

It was very good and easy to make. The only issue I had was getting the rice together. I do not have a rice press, so I tried to make them by hand. The rice cakes came out looking like two different aliens made a very ugly baby. Presentation aside, I was happy with them. I may go with low sodium soy sauce as they were a bit salty, or half and half. Will definitely make again.
One of our most favorite recipes!
love it

I've been using this recipe for years. Like others noted, simply cooking calrose rice and no vinegar is just fine. I also use a long sushi press that covers the entire sheet and 2 1/3 spam slices. After wrapping the long roll, I cut into small bite size pieces. Great for parties and hungry coworkers.

We followed the recipe exactly as it said. And it turned out amazing! Just like the musubi back in Hawaii! The only thing we did differently is use less rice (didn’t want to get full too quick!) we were able to make like 6-10 musubi per container. My biggest tip is to try not to cook it when it’s soaked in the marinated sauce. Or else it’ll “burn” a little more than you want. Also, that rice vinegar is key!!!! Balances out the saltiness!!! We added scrambled eggs and avocado for taste.Enjoy!!!!

Just a suggestion, cut the bottom side of the spam can and you can use that as a “musubi” mold. Place that on top of nori, add rice, press down, add spam and press down to release mold then fold nori over. I don’t eat spam but my family does and we normally don’t use sushi rice but regular calories medium grain rice and fry the spam in shoyu and sugar. This recipe sounds interesting to make for my family. Thanks!
Added a little mirin to the marinade and decrease some sugar. Also used less rice vinegar for the rice.. good!
this is so good!! I want it every day now! I made mine with avocado and it came out so yummy!!!
My skeptical family enjoyed this. Cooked the marinade down to dip the musubi in.
My kids loved this! Thanks for sharing!

Excellent recipe. Used mirin instead of oyster sauce and added fresh ginger to the marinade, so searing it smelled like heaven. Sliced some Japanese pickled daikon (the bright yellow stuff) to go in. After forgetting to mix furikake into the rice we just dipped the finished musubi into it between bites. That's a win.
Yummy ??

Most amazing spam musubi I’ve ever made. I substituted Aji-Mirin for Rice Vinegar since I didn’t have have any on hand. Like another reviewer, I also recommend using roasted/salted seaweed. I bought mine from a Japanese market.

I used about three cups of rice for my recipe and used thicker slices with two cans of spam instead of the one. I thought that the 6 tablespoons of rice vinegar was questionable so i halved it and it was definitely too much for my taste. It doesnt really fit in with the salty sweet taste of the spam after it was cooked. The amount of vinegar just took over the taste. Next time i’ll just use two tablespoons and try that out. Maybe even less.
I made this a little smaller for hors d'oeuvre, the glaze was delicious.

I was throwing my sister a Luau party and was looking for easy ideas. This receipt was easy to make and with a little tweak on the second try was perfect. 
I subestute regular spam with low sodium light spam. Just as tasty lower calories. It turned out fabulous. People that came that never eat spam nor would ever, ate this. The Nori was too chewy on the first try, but after it sat for a few minutes and was moist it was easier to eat. So the second time I made it, which was today. I ran the Nori gently through the water before setting on my prep mat and adding the rice and spam. Super easy.
I did this for a Luau party and it was a hit. Super easy!

I made it recently following this recipe, I bought everything and cooked everything(except letting the rice sit for 4 hours). I can’t eat this following the recipe. I was already concerned with the sodium content and ignored it. I ate two pieces as I felt like I wasn’t going to make it...the salt content makes it unbearable to eat anymore of it. I still have the salty taste in my mouth as I’m writing this review. 0/10 wouldn’t try this recipe again
I think it’s awesome! I personally tried a rolled version with rice paper instead of nori.
I substituted mango habañero for the oyster sauce, and strawberry preserves for the sugar. Also I don't own a press but I made due with a couple of knives.
Loved it!
You can microwave the sugar and the vinegar mix as well to cut back on prep time. Then add this mixture to the rice and mix well.

So yummy! Wow what a treat. This was my first time making it for myself and my husband. Normally we just buy it but we bought our musubi mold and it worked great. I mainly used this recipe to get the marinade I was looking for. I didn't bother soaking the rice. I would definitely say follow the rule of only marinating the spam for 5 minutes because any longer and it gets very salty. I did not have any rice vinegar so I didn't use it but it tasted just like the musubi I normally buy.

Great recipe. My second time making spam musubi. Brings me back to Hawaii! I used low sodium spam but should've used less soy sauce. It was a tad bit salty for me. Husband had it and really enjoyed it. I only used two sheets of nori and toasted it on the burner and cut into 1.5 inch strips with scissors. Like someone else mentioned, I used the spam container as my mold. Use Saran Wrap to line the mold then add rice. With a wet spoon, press down the rice. Pull the Saran Wrap out with the rice. Will definitely make again.

I was born and raised in Hawaii (Oahu, house on Kaneohe Bay - such a rough upbringing...). And if you live in Hawaii, you either love spam, or you think it's gross. Most of us are the former, and love this Frankenstein'd meat.

Anyhow, just want to say I've been using this recipe for a while as it captures my preferred flavor of spam musubi. You can, of course, substitute chicken, bacon, pork, etc., but only in addition to also having dedicated spam musubi as well. Because if you make this without any spam, you are not worthy.

If you're in the mood to build further upon this recipe, then you can do what I dub as the Royal Hawaiian Spam Musubi. To do this, cook some bacon and scramble some eggs. When "assembling" your masterpiece, do the rice half-way, then add a bacon layer, topped by the egg, then add the spam layer. Wrap it up fully in seaweed (only flaw in this posted recipe is the thin band of seaweed - this baby needs to be fully wrapped in seaweed) and you have a nice variant of the base spam musubi.

That aside, even if you just do the spam musubi per the directions, it's great.
I added scrambled egg on top layer. It turned out pretty good.

Loved it. A friend made this dish for me a while ago, and I've been craving it since. Working with the sushi rice was a little tricky but honestly its an easy and tasty dish. I recommend this and hope to make it again.

ONO! Brought back memories of living in Hawaii 20 years ago. I did a few things different though. I left out the oyster sauce and used teriyaki sauce instead of shoyu. I also used turkey spam as I no longer eat pork. I've done a variation using tinned corned beef and that was delicious also.
I added fried eggs to a few. Ono!

This was great. I used medium-grain white rice, which worked fine. I also sprinkled some furikame in between the rice and the Spam for extra flavor. I liked it better when the nori was cut smaller, so I cut the nori by another half for the last half of the batch. As recommended by others, I lowered the heat to medium. Will make again.

I tried Spam Musubi at a local Hawaiian restaurant and loved it so I had to try and make it at home. 

I didn't have 4 hours to marinate the rice, so I used short grain rice, rinsed it 3x until it ran clear and then cooked in my rice cooker according to the package directions. It came out fantastic and really shortened the recipe time. 

I also used the low sodium variety of spam. Otherwise, I followed the recipe exactly and it turned out so good! My friends commented that they would never have guessed it had spam in it. Marinating and cooking the spam really changes the flavor and texture. It's salty, but the rice is not so it creates a fantastic savory unctuous balance.
It is easy to make ! I love this receipe.
Yummy recipe! Tweaked the flavor up a bit by dipping the cooked spam into the marinate sauce and also adding a spoonful of the marinate sauce into the rice prior to putting the spam to the rice :)
Both times I tried to make this the sugar/oyster/soy mixture burned by the time I got to the second side. I don't think I'll try a third time :-(

We didn't marinate it but glazed it in the pan while frying and it still turned out great! I think next time I'll roll it instead of layering it to get more seaweed taste which really highlights and binds all the flavours together.
I like another style better, just regular rice and a teriyaki based sauce. The sushi rice is a little off tasting with the spam for me.
I used sushi rice. Loved the marinade. 4 cups of sushi rice, 3-4 cans of spam. Toast seaweed, put spam in first

I love musubis and this recipe is great. However, it calls for oil but doesn't include it in the steps. I figured I was supposed to use it to fry the Spam so that's what I did. I just took a tray of about 30 of them to my husband's work. I used an Asian hot sauce for half of them. I added it to half of the soy sauce mixture, and added a thin strip of Jalapeno, between the Nori strip and the Spam. They are yummy!
Beyond delicious! Addictive.

I think the addition of the oyster sauce is pretty good...I always use aloha shoyu...you definitely do not have to soak your rice for 4 hours...the secret to getting a good sauce is to fry the spam and while it's hot dip it into the shoyu mixture onto steamed rice ...making sure to generously dip so that the sauce soaks a little into the rice while its wrapped and wrap quickly....the steam when the musubi is wrapped with saran wrap will soften the wrap to the correct consistency. You can purchase the correct sized wrap at the Asian store it comes in packs of 100 to make it easier...the above picture barely has anything...you can use other things but the spam, sauce, rice combo if done correctly should be all you will need...because there are alot of flavors already

I made this for a luau and was skeptical since I'd never eaten or made anything like it but it was delicious! The spam tasted like teriyaki chicken and the rice was delicious with the vinegar. I borrowed my sisters musabi press and would definitely recommend using one as it sped up the process and they all came out uniform. I sprayed the press with cooking spray to keep the rice from sticking.

Made as directed, and wanted to like it..but found it just OK. Kids ate it, but the novelty of Nori wore off once they tasted it. Found the oyster sauce a bit overpowering at times. Again OK, and probably a taste you grow into.
I love this recipe! I've made it multiple times and it's better than any Spam Musubi I've bought from a restaurant. Highly recommend!

I grew up in Hawai'i and I love this recipe. I like to cook things I grew up eating for my boyfriend, who is from New York, and didn't know the goodness of Hawaiian food. Now he requests spam musubi all the time. :)
This was exactly what I wanted! Loved it.
I've tried a couple of musubi recipes before this one and they were just ok, I really loved the tase that this mixture gave the musubi.
I've tried a couple of musubi recipes before this one and they were just ok, I really loved the tase that this mixture gave the musubi.
Tastes just like what I got in Hawaii! Can i say...although I didn't soak the rice for 4 hours...just washed it thoroughly....came out wonderful
Great recipe! I didn't have oyster sauce so I substituted fish sauce. It tasted about the same. Kids love this!
This is one of my fav anything musubi recipes! You can also try it with a hot link sausage too! You wouldn't be disappointed :)

To save time, I just cook the rice in rice cooker and add the vinegar to it while cooking. I also don't cut the nori in half and end up using two nori sheets per musubi.

Oh, and I use an asian sauce container, the small rectangular ones, as the perfect mold for the rice.

I've never tried true Hawaiian musubi so I wasn't sure what to expect. I followed the recipe ingredients exactly and flavor was good but a tad too salty. Will use low sodium soy sauce in the future. Molding the rice without a musubi maker was disastrous for me, so I ended up slicing the cooked spam into strips and rolling it in the rice covered nori on a sushi rolling mat. Fun change of pace but not something I would crave.

I live part time in Hawaii with my dad and growing up there I love love love the food! I eat all kinds of local food. This is my all time favorite! My dad buys it for me all the time from the Minit Stop down the road. The recipe is delicious except when I make it I don't use the oyster sauce or the vinegar.
This was ok.
Tried this tonight and really liked it! Had it with some maki. A bit salty so it's important to get the rice to spam ratio right!
This was suprisingly tasty! We made it for a luau and it was gobbled up immediately. Give yourself some time to put it together, it is well worth the time.
It was good, but I prefer my mom's marinade without the oyster sauce (I was born and raised in Hawaii and I guess I am used to her version).
spam and rice you cannot go wrong, cheap an easy classic.. reminds me of Hawaii every time.
My son fell in love with this when visiting Hawaii. Great for kids to participate in the kitchen. Bad for those on low sodium diets.

I lived in Hawaii for many years and your recipe is spot on except for one thing. I have no idea why you'd soak your rice at all, much less for 4 hours. I put the rice into the rice cooker... add water and push the button. Perfect rice in less than 30 minutes. A fun way to shape the rice so it fits the spam slices just right, is to pat the rice out on a sheet of parchment paper to the thickness you want. Then use the spam can like a cookie cutter to cut the rice. (Works best if you cut off both the top and bottom of the can)
This was really good and the kids loved it. It makes a great lunch

Is this supposed to use seasoned rice vinegar? I didn't like it with just rice vinegar. Much better after I added seasoned rice vinegar to it. I had a horrible time with my sushi molds. One was just ridiculously large and the other was too small. So I ended up having to cut the spam to fit. It came out more appetizer size, which end the end was better. This is only a four for me when using the seasoned rice vinegar. After reading the reviews about too much marinade I cut the amount in half and it was perfect. My kids liked this one.
This was an amazing recipe. I plan on substituting the spam with other meat sources and see howit turns out. My partner and I ate 5 musubi's each and still wanted more!

It was very good. Better than the Hawaiian fast food up the street. I cut the vinegar in half because I was afraid of what the hubby would think. I was still able to taste it fine. I put ckicken instead of spam to try something different. I already know what spam musubi is like. Thanks, we all loved the formula.
Nice little kick with the oyster sauce. You can also try experimenting with other meats. i.e. Teriyaki grilled chicken, kalua pork, Teri/miso salmon, boneless Korean bbq beef. Ono!

I made these & took them to a get together with friends. Immediately our host perked up and was like "Is this Musubi?!?!?!" and started chowing down on them. Afterwards he asked me if I had steamed it, and then let me know that many Hawaiian natives steam them to tighten the seaweed. Will do next time, but he sat there all night telling stories about when he lived in Hawaii. Must have been close & it tasted pretty awesome too.

I grew up eating Spam and Spam Musubi. I always make Spam Musubi using a "basic sauce", Spam and nori. I cook rice first then set it aside to cool a bit while I assemble other ingredients. I bring Aloha soy sauce and brown sugar to a medium boil in a saucepan until sugar dissolves. I just eyeball the amount of soy sauce and brown sugar, to taste, never measuring. I omitted the oyster sauce (never used it). I don't fry the spam in vegetable oil. I just cut up the spam in thick slices and add it to the saucepan. I also roast the nori right before putting everything together. Using a musubi maker I place the nori inside, add rice and press it into the mold, add a slice of cooked spam, another layer of rice on top and press the top musubi maker onto everything together tightly. I then remove the mold and use a sharp knife to cut the musubi in half. Sometimes I make this for breakfast or lunch. While I do have "my own" way of making Spam Musubi sauce (without oyster sauce), others may find adding a little more seasoning to theirs, such as this recipe, more suitable. Thou Spam Musubi is easy to make, it is a filling and tasty snack. Some people add nori furikake and other ingredients to the Spam Musubi to jazz it up. You will find Spam Musubi anywhere here in Hawaii, even at the 7-Eleven stores. This can be served as an appetizer, part of an okazuya and a snack on-the-go! Very popular and Onolicious!!

The teriyaki sauce is just perfect! I will definitely reuse this for other meats. I simply followed the instructions for cooking Japanese rice from the instructions on the bag. I think it is much faster than soaking the rice.

This recipe was great! I was going to go with a teriyaki glaze for flavor but found this recipe for the spam sauce and from the rave reviews with the oyster sauce, I had to try this instead. It was delish! I had my Husband cut the bottom off the spam can to use for the mold, pressed the seasoned sushi rice (another recipe) in it, shook on some furikake then popped it out of the mold, added the cooked spam and nori. Good Hawaiian memories there.
I marinated in teriyaki sauce instead, and used the spam tin as a sushi press, then ate them with sriracha sauce

Great recipie, very similar to the one I learned back when I lived in Mililani.

A great addition is to add 3 Tbsp of toasted sesame seeds to the rice before forming it for a nice flavor (thats the way Auntie Kaliha always made it).

Also, if you have a rice cooker (you can buy a 6 cup one at Wal*Mart for cheap), you can skip the soak for 4 hours step and have tasty musubi in about 35 minutes total!

One of my roommates @ college was from HI & when I was in the dorm's, I was the only one on the floor of twently girls NOT from HI -- they showed me how to roll sushi & we would make this for us all when we went tailgating or just when hangin around! Awesome tasting & if you haven't tried it before - DO ! ! It is a FAB snack, appetizer, meal!
Make sure you really pan-sear the spam. Almost to a burnt crisp. Reduce liquid ingredients by half. Original portions makes too much marinade.
My fiance loved this!

I was sceptical to try this, but my stepson is a Spamaholic...saw it on the Food Networks "Best thing I ever ate" and thought I'd give it a try! I was pleasantly surprised! I did use "sticky" sushi rice, and cut the bottom of the spam can off to use for a mold!

I make this ALL the time. I usually change it to 40 servings because everyone loves it and it goes fast! I marinate the spam for several hours rather than just 5 minutes. When I increase the servings, I decrease the rice vinegar some, otherwise it's too strong. The sugar can also be easily decreased if you like (oyster sauce is already sweet). I also add Furikake rice reasoning to the rice. I wrap each spam musubi in plastic wrap (after it's cooled). If you put it in the fridge, the rice can get hard. I leave it out for a max of 2 days & its still good, but it's usually gone long before that.
This is very good and authentic. I cut down the ratio of soy sauce, oyster sauce, and sugar because you only use a tiny portion of that, and the rest goes to waste.

It was alright, but a bit too sweet for my taste. I usually use splenda and a bit of mirin instead to cut down on sugar. On a side note, MUSUBI is not SUSHI. Sushi actually means "vinegared rice". Musubi is also called Onigiri in Japan depending on the region.

A Samoan friend made some for a get-together but didn't leave the recipe. My son and his friends asked me to make some for them and so I found this recipe. It is just as good if not better than the musubi she made!
had issues with my rice so ended up frying the spam and adding the rice. I had to make the next day because everyone I was camping with wanted more.
Been in Kona enough to know that this is as close to the real thing as it gets, awesome thanks for the share!
